I'd be careful using the word "prove" or derivatives thereof too much, because so little in the real science world can be literally *proven* to a philosophical-grade standard.

Even in real science you still have to take quite a lot on faith - society wouldnt work otherwise, we would literally spend our entire live re-confirming everything we heard, buried in research papers and labwork. Managing this combination of evidence, faith-based reassurance, and confirmation is a large part of being a scientist.

The crux is "provide evidence", these sorts of people seem to be sure that all the evidence against is fake or somehow misunderstood, and all of their evidence is rock-solid. This is the main source of frustration as it appears that they judge a large pool of evidence either way based solely on opinion and offer no other explanation. Most times, neither party will be in a position to offer any further reinforcement other than their personal assurance, which is of course, worthless. Thus the frustration is very hard to prevent.

If anyone ever says "This PROVES that" then you can almost always demonstrate that it isn't really proof, damaging what might otherwise be a good point - this works for both sides of course.

Ie: a photo Niel Armstrong took on the Moon ISN'T technically "proof" men went to the moon, but it IS pretty strong *evidence*. And you need equally strong evidence against to refute it, you don't need "proof", which is good because it is exceedingly rare.

In the end, it's just going to separate the smart ones from the fools, and I want that. Let's have "fun" with that guy in the link, and just roll with it.
